SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A NOTE OF EXTREME GRATITUDE TO THE PERSON WHO COMPLETES THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life, because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences to report. Some of the questions here will not apply to you; others may be answered in more than one way. If there are sufficient reasons to answer the questionnaires, it is best to answer them accurately or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1946 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one person of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Malcolm William Anderson, M.A.S.C.C.H.M.

2. Your address: 4447 19th Ave., North Bokem.

3. Date: March 12, 1914.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Ontario, Canada.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thomas Scott, M.A.S.C.C.H.M.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 12, 1914.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Ontario, Canada; Alberta; April 1904 to April 1914.

8. How old were you when you first came to western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.) I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To get away from the land and see something new.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

    Through other people - others reading me.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

We were in favor of it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad CPR, Hanover, Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

Very ordinary harvest, dry season trips, no typhoid.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Chester.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the Meadow Lake district now known as Makwa Point.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I put in seven years working for others and logging contracts on my own in the Crows Nest Pass mostly in Blairmore.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on farms and saw mills in Ontario, logging mostly in the Crows Nest and worked on farms in Saskatchewan homestead.
12. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad / P.R. Railroad - typew.

13. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way! Meeting with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

Story ordinary farmer - typew.

14. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Sherwood

15. Where did you settle or take up land?

For the Meadows

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Saskatoon

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on farms and mills

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on farms and mills
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not relatives frequently (citizens seldom)

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage:
   Married at Malvern Nov. 15 - 1943

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   I doubt it.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   There is not any particular incident that stands out at first it was about 75 miles of bush tracks to Post Office or store as this country settled up. The distance became less until today there are 3 miles from the Sand. Malvern Hamlet and 30 miles by rail head at Mudan Lake.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Not a great deal and until 1928 all by horses and wagon. Used to go out to the Prairies thrice in the fall until about 1924 when we began to have sufficient crops to carry on with.

22. Include numbers of your family (brothers, sisters, etc.) cause list.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   Answer: 1927

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Answer: 1910

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Answer: St. Walburg, Will 1932 - Windsor Lake Office

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Conditions gradually improved as stated, trade got better, car travel was possible after about 1926.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Answer: Every 3 or 4 months

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Answer: They knew how to do that in those parts right, but I don't know.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We started buying from mail orders about 1914 and still buy towels and clothes and things about 50% of our clothes are bought that way. Local stores have never carried a very full line.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Answer: Not yet

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I did not intend to stay at first, it was my intention to go to the Grand Trunk Pacific then go down to Prince Rupert and so on, but by the time I was ready and when I went there and I decided to stay here.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 
   March 1926

26. Did you own a car before 1914, when did you buy it? 
   No

27. What was your traveling conveyance? How far from your house?
   St. Walburg, Mo. 1932. I didn't have a vehicle.

28. Did you continue to travel by horse (indicate any changes due to new forms of transportation, better means of travel, etc.)?

Conditions gradually improved as stated, we got better cars. Travel was preferable after about 1926.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Every 3 or 4 weeks

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Every few months that's when parking was available.

31. Then (if ever) did you begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   We started buying from mail order about 1914 and still buy underwear and clothes and things around 80% of our purchases are through the mail order catalogues.

Clothes are very good - that way great stores have never carried a very full line.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Not yet

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I decided to stay the first time I was there and go back to my old job.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

This district's first settler started here in what year and was followed by that full by 8774 more of us and we are all here now.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

This country's big settlement was in the 30s and they started till about '35 and started moving out and I would estimate that '60 or '70 moved out by 1944.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was elected to this for 12 years: 1925 - 37
President Modern Home Co-op Postage Stamp Co. 1891
Makwa Roadmen for 10 years
Director South Porage Co-op Creamery for last 10 years
Program Committee Member last 2
Was connected with Audit Office at B Makwa

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I do not know that we were first in any
We had these certainly among the first
Small 4-H club organized a lodge
Jamboree 1925 Combined 1942
Brotherhood started 1935
Work on homestead 1921

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Makwa is Ojibway for Bear and another
Town or Makwa Union flows just south
We when we picked a name for the Post Office that was selected at a meeting about
30 settlers here at that time about 1950
and the name still is used; though there are
2 Post Offices now North and South Makwa
The other names Rabbit River, Horsehead river
would have been named by the Indians as they
were in common use when I arrived
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

No. Anything in that line I had was burned in my house in 1942.

Pov Nielson - Edmonton

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Imagine roads caused the most important changes here. That and the employment people from the south during the drought period certainly had more to do with opening up this north country than anything else.
Of course the roads followed the people and the new farms around.
